intro: Gynoxys hutchisonii, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower, is a striking herbaceous plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its showy, orange to red composite flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 1 to 3 meters, featuring narrow, lance-shaped leaves and a robust root system. Its flowers bloom in the summer, attracting a variety of pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Gynoxys hutchisonii is often cultivated for its ornamental value and can thrive in full sun with well-drained soil.
